text: Bottle [2007 vintage, first bottling] shared @ tasting. Hazy orange pink color, small off-white head. Aroma is a little faint but theres a nice subtle fruity touch there with a slightly sharp fruitpeel sour-bitter bite. Tastes like that as well, a little touch of sour-bitter in the beginning but a very smooth subtle fruity sourness underneath. Soft, peaches, a hint of orangepeel. Nice!

2007 vintage bottle shared. Pours cloudy orange with a ring off white head. Aroma of citrus, light barnyard, soft funk, peaches, light woody. Flavour is light moderate acidic, surely softened with age. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Overall, its really good but this is surely very much softened with age in every way.
Bottle shared thanks to dfonorow. Poured golden orange with white head. Aroma is slight sour acid citrus. Light carb med bod. Taste slight sour well balanced.
Trade from Flechtfighter, thnks buddy. Unclear yellow body with a medium white head. Funky, cellar, tart, vinegar, fruity, yeast, brett. Delicious.

Bottle @ 14.000th Tasting. Thanks to Hallinghansen (Tha Man) for sharing. Pours cloudy deep golden with a white head. Fruit, funk, peach, manuer and mild almond. Nose is a tad better - really deep and complex. Georgeous stuff!

The elusive Cable Car, finally got my shot. Sampled many times at GABF 2014. I think between friends and multiple times through the line I drank close to a pint of this stuff. Appearance was hazy golden with a big white head and great lacing. Really funky, citrusy, lemon peel, some urine/barnyard notes, a touch of grass and oaky aroma. Taste is tropical fruits - mango & pineapple - somewhat lemony, light urine, woody, light spice, horse blanket, herbs and wax with a medium sour finish. Medium body with high carbonation. Incredible funky and complex, yet highly drinkable and refreshing. So much Awesomeness! American geueze!
Tasted at GABF. This is at the top of american sours I have tasted. Straight sour with tons of fruity subtlety. Amazing stuff.

outstanding aroma of funky apricot and roasted pecans. tastes of sweet  and sour apricot, nutty biscuits and pecans in a subtle way. sweet caramel swirling in there, too. sticky mouthfeel but that nonetheless doesnt over-coat the tongue.

GABF. Golden hue with white head. Aroma is straw, peppercorn, slight funk, lemon, grass. Medium light body and zesty carbonation. Taste is dry sweetness with a tart following and slight peppercorn finish. Overall this is a really nice brew.

Bottle: 2013. Murky; almost fully opaque with a vibrant, golden-orange color. Creamy, foamy, eggshell head wafts softly atop the radiant brew. Beautiful aroma of sour lemon, yogurt, lactic & lightly acetic acid, sweet-tart candy, tart citrus, white grape, slightly vinous oak, & some back-end helpings of moderate funk; musty hay, damp cheesecloth, & some sweaty barnyard notes. The flavor is brilliantly acidic & tart, but not so over the top that it becomes a burden to drink. Vinous white wine grape skins, rich woody oak, lemon & bursting citrus flesh, sour lacto with a mild yogurty tone, & a modest funky character sifting throughout. Lingering notes of wet cork, cellar floor, lightly lactic lemon, white grape, & dry wood. Sharp & crisp mouth feel. This beer is fantastic; the hype is pretty much warranted for this. Wonderfully complex & pleasantly sour without inducing any ulcers or GERD which goes miles for drinkability.

Bottles poured at toronado anniversary. Shared a 08,12, and 13. 12 was my favorite. Poured a nice gold color with small fizzy white head. Smell is slight lemony and sour. Taste is incredibly clean and tart. Delicious and easy to drink. Best unfruited sour I've had

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle at goulét brewery bus tour. Whale. Hazy golden pour with no head. Fruit puckering sour flavors, nice flavors. Great aromas, tart and funky.

750 ml bottle is 2007 vintage shared by ygtbsm94. Thanks Brad! Pours a hazy golden orange color with a small ring of bubbles clinging to the glass. Aroma is lemon citrus, barnyard funk, and light oak notes. Flavor is very complex: grapefruit and lemon citrusy sourness, puckering, balanced and quenching. Alcohol is well masked, thin to medium bodied, delicious. From notes 1/23/10 (Geist Dark Lord tasting)
Kind of a clear yellow. Aroma is brettish. Taste is Brett and sour. Still a solid beer but tastes more rare than amazing.

Wild wild lemons and more lemons..very pleasing lemons and some grassy horse goat...sounds wierd but perfect balance with all these ingenious flavors. The lemons I love in the wild style ales...perfect for summer. Solid A
Pours a deep golden orange with no head. Aroma of peaches, nectarines, oak and funk. Taste is sour, fruity, peaches and nectarines, funk and oak. So tasty so complex.

Aroma: Lemons, Hay, Grassy, Mild Lactic Acid

Appearance: Hazy Golden Straw Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head Ring, Decent Lacing

Taste: Lemon Rind, Hay, Mild Apricots, Mild Lactic Acid

Mouthfeel: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Semi Tart

2008 Bottle at Toronado Pub, San Diego. Appearance is light golden peach. Aroma is mild sour with no real funk. Taste is low carbonation - close to perfection with the profile: very smooth, good level of acid, mild oaky quality. This IS NOT a fruit sour, just mild woodiness and sour. FInish is very tangy. Overall, a great sour - very well balanced and straight up Maybe nothing on the lambics, but very well done. Gets better as you attune to the lack of fruit and funk.

750 ml bottle

I was not expecting to get to try this despite visiting Toronado as it can be hard to get. When the wait staff asked me as I was closing the tab if I wanted a bottle it took exactly three seconds to say Yes. I am glad too - this is a world class sour that put even the Almanac Bourbon Barrel Peche to shame.

Aroma / Appearance - A golden body shimmers with life and light peachy edges. Lemons, oak, and a lingering tartness give this an edge a bit stronger than the average sour but without being vinegary. it almost could be mistaken for a gueuze.

Flavor / Palate - Oak and lemon lightly play across the tongue. The tartness grows until crashing into sour waves on the back of the throat. Almost like a dry champagne it sparkles the entire time. This is one of those beers that everyone should get a chance to try and proves that Lost Abbey is still on top of their game.

2008 bottle thanks to Diego! Pours a cloudy orange with paperthin white head that diminishes to nothing. The aroma is strong funk, oak, lemon, and yeast. Thin mouthfeel with light sourness, oak, with lingering tart finish. Held up very well, so impressive.

2010 bottle generously shared by AdamJackson on 3/15/14Walked in to the tasting and this bottle was already open, waiting patiently for me and definitely beckoning. Hows that for the first beer of the tasting? Save the best for first! And as far as I was concerned, this was the best of show (though I got too drunk and had to leave before Duck Duck was opened, so who knows).Anyhow, the aroma was a pretty quickly decided 10, for me. I started with not even an inch of glorious, clear, ruby liquid but even that yielded a bountiful, rich, very strong aroma of perfectly wedded sour acids. Acetic acid was gentle at this point and only added enough vinegar-like notes to punctuate the style while the malo-lactic portion was soft, rich and divine. Smelled like it had cherries jumping out of the glass. Tons of black pepper, cherry pit and very light vanilla. Bone dry tartness lingering. Wow, if this stuff smells this much like cherry, I wonder what the actual Kriek version is like...Beautifully flavorful, as well, with a very dry, light body, leaving only traces of candied prunes and light caramel while the lactic acid and black pepper phenols do all the work. Hints of light base malt sweetness provides excellent balance and the beer seems neither overly/obnoxiously sour, nor lacking in any sour character. Really, really good and well worth the 3 to 4 hundred dollar price tag that I didnt have to pay ;) Thanks Adam! What a guy!

2010 bottle shared by Adam Jackson @ RBNEG. Pours a pale yellow with a one finger white head. White wine aroma with an acidic fruitiness. Touch of wood and leather. Semi sweet flavor with more light fruits tempered with a light sour funk. Drying palate with carbonation. Huge thanks to Adam for bringing this.

Bottle shared by Adam Jackson during the RBNG. Hazy pale yellow color, still good carbonation level. Aroma of tart lemons, moldy oak, sour grapes. 
Flavor is much the same as the nose with a sharp acidic sensation in the back of the taste buds. Very dry texture. I guess everybody goes nuts over this because of the rarity. Its a great sour if youre into that sort of thing.

Big thanks to Adamjackson for the share on this. Your typical Adamjackson whale tasting. Nobody showed up because they all asked around and heard Adam only has whale tastings. Really nice sour that smells fantastic. I get so much in this; lemon, tropical fruits, grapes, oak, white wine, leather, and basement. Taste is moderately tart with more fruits and funk. Overall great stuff,

Bottle from AdamJackson. Shared during out NE Meetup in the Waterbury Best Western. Peach skins met with sweat and kelp. Bittersweet, with a touch of sea salt, marzipan, and goat butter. Boost level #6.5.

2010 Bottle, 750 ML split a stupid amount of ways. 

A - Straw yellow appearance. Small whisp of the head and leaves a nice 1 finger head that fades fast.

S - The nose is huge! A very acidic, lots of grape skin, hay, rope and leather. Super funky with lemon as well. 

T - Taste is even better. I get a hint of butter but really, its a lemon lime funk bomb, a lot of rope, minor fecal taste (yes seriously) and I get a really great grapefruit rind, ropey and sweet. 

M - Insanely dry, super bright carbonation and mouthfeel. Really excellent. This makes the beer amazing.

O - Well, I didnt hype this one up too long or sit on it forever. I traded for it to enjoy on my 2,000th beer rating and BOOM enjoying it with some nice friends from RateBeer. Excited to have this with you all. Thanks!
2010 bottle. Taste at RBNG. Thanks Adam! Pours chardonnay white gold. No head. Scent is floral, white wine. Taste is very tart, peach and lemon some oak to balance.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2015 Huge thanks to Adam Jackson, tart and light with acrid sourness, very nice , this is how all sours should taste. Increditble complexity with fruit, berry, and cittrus flavors, then comes some spices and herbs. Great great stuff.

Sampled at Woodshop 2011. Pours a hazy bright golden color with minimal head. Aromas of grapefruit, lemonade, acid, medium funk, overripe lime. The palate is nice and drying, but not overly acidic, with flavors of tart peach, pink lemonade, slight funk. Well balanced.

This one poured a hazy darker yellow to orange with an off white head. Aroma was very bright, lots of sweet bread, orange zest, lemon, mild funk, and wheaty yeasty. Flavor was similar, lots going on here, overripened peaches, coriander, cracked wheat, light white wine, light funk quality too. Very nice.

2013 bottle thanks to Chris. Big thanks! Pours a cloudy orange with a fluffy white head. Brett aroma with some tropical fruit aroma. Taste is very well balanced. Starts sweet and finishes slightly tart. Extremely easy drinking. Medium to light body. Medium carb.

Pour is golden yellow with a bubbly white head. Nose has very faint barrel with hints of acetic acid, notes of leathery bret and orange peel with a nice vinous quality. Taste is very drinkable, sour white grape skins and citrus with hints of oak and vanilla. Faint leathery bret and a touch of citrus towards the back of the palate. Lighter body and strong carbonation (shocking) with a dry and lightly sour finish. Very delicate flavors and pretty well done.

750 ml bottle shared by brew3crew (notes). Pours a hazy golden color with a medium sized white head that disappeared quickly. The aroma had a pleasant tart citrus and tropical fruit character, oak, funk, with a mild acidity. The flavor is much of the same; tart citrus and tropical fruit, mild funk, oak with mild acidity. This is not a sour bomb, but more of a session sour that is wicked hard to find and obtain. I had been looking to try this for some time and was not disappointed.

Bottle thanks to Sean! Been lucky enough to try this beer a couple times. Pours hazy golden with an off white head. Aroma is straw, barnyard and a good amount of funk. Flavor is barnyard, earthy with tons of sour notes. Light bodied with little carbonation.

Bottle from a friend....flat. May be stored badly or off cork??? Ruined the palate, and there was no aroma due to that fact. Taste really good. I am sure if I got a proper bottle or if it was stored properly it would be a 4.5+ hope I get another chance to retry and re rate

Bottle (750 ml). 2012 vintage. Pours deep yellow straw color with a small poorly retained white head and some lacing. Aroma is slightly funky, with barnyard, oak and slight fruity notes. Taste is not too sour but with complex funky notes, citrus, oak, Brett and balanced sweetness. Mouthfeel is really dry, tart, and crisp. An outstanding wild ale. I loved it. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2013 Vintage. Bottle at Toronado, pours a hazy golden with a small white head. Aroma brings out complex oak barrels, some funkiness, and dried light fruits (subtle apricots). Flavour is very complex, with oak barrels, a mixture of dry light fruits, and low-to-medium tartness. Very elegant, with all flavours working harmoniously. Finishes on slightly vinegary notes, as well as light fruits and oak. Definitely overrated, but certainly a delicious beer.

Aroma- Lemon, must, & vinegar, not overpowering, just pleasantly present.
Appearance- hazy golden color with a thin film of head.
Taste- Light sweetness, and medium sour. Tart like cherries and maybe green apple, some nice lacto acetic quality as well.
Palate- Light bodied and lively mouthfeel.
Overall- Really good sour, wasnt worth the 45 min line I had to wait in to get an 8 oz pour but none the less very glad I tried it.

A - pours hazy glowing golden with low small bubbled eggshell head. S - agro straight from the bottle but mellows amazingly well. Nice sour lemons and vinegar with nice strong funk. A really nice sour after it sits in the glass for a bit. Honey and lemon meringue pie crust. Hints of sweet cream butterNeat. M - tart but not too much. Rounded and a nice balance of sweet and sour with funk. So nice. T - sour lemons and vinegar up front. Lemon tart with crust. Citrusy and sweet with a lacto tinge. O - a really nice American sour. Im glad I stumbled into the release. 4.3

On tap at the Toronado. Aroma was clean Brett, freshly-squeezed Meyer lemon juice, Rainier cherries, and a slight funk. Flavor was very much the same with maybe the cleanest palate on a beer I've ever had. So crisp, so refreshing... I could drink a ton of this superb beer.

im gonna do to reviews in one here for my #100 we had the 2013 vintage on tap @toronado SF i will rate them soon which is top notch by the way. any ways it poured a glowing bright slight hazy yellow nose was grannt smith apples very tart nose and a mouth watering taste so crisp not over the top pucker but still a amazing sour brew. next we got to share a bottle of 2007 which was unreal really hadnt lost and edge still well carbonated and nice fruit nose poured a little hazy off orange brownish taste was still tart and some nice green apple notes still held up
The most recent batch is absolutely amazing, really tart but nice stone fruit characters and a good lightly funky character, just awesome.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2013 Sampled from a bottle at Where the Wild Beers Are - October 5, 2013. Special thanks to weinando for the 411 on the sorta-concealed pouring of this beer. Yellow/orange pour with a white head. Lemony and fruity. Slightly sour, but not overly so. Light and crisp. Great beer!

Review # 800

750 ml bottle served in a Lost Abbey Teku glass. 2012 vintage generously shared by kevanb, thanks Kevan! 

A: Pours a hazy yellow color with a white head forming on the pour. A thin white head forms on the pour and recedes to a thick wispy ring.

S: Lactic and lemony. Minimal funky notes. Some straw with some lemon grass. Tart and slightly acidic. White grape notes and stone fruit flesh.

T: The taste pairs pretty with the nose, although the sourness gets amped up a bit. Nice little pucker with some great fruitiness. Lemon grass with a minimal tartness. Lactic sweetness. Sweet oak notes with a nice light fruity flesh presence. Vibrant stone fruit notes.

M: Light bodied with a great, lively carbonation. A little jowl pucker with the sourness. Dry finish.

O: Delicate, but vibrant. Delicious American Wild. The fruity notes that came out were great despite no fruit being added. Thanks again to Kevan for sharing.

Serving type: bottle

07-14-2013

Bottle poured for my 32nd birthday. .. great bottle to drink to the entire thing!?

Smell was tart stone fruit and brett. Flavor of peach, apricot and lemon. Very tart but not overpoweringly sour.

Bottle. The pour is a nice bright orange. The aroma is a muted sour. The taste is not overly sour, but nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2009 bottle graciously shared by cpferris. thanks chad! Super clean and refreshing soft yogurt and touch of lemon. Dusty cobweb funk. Some leather. Acidity in check. Refreshing tasty beer. Easy drinking. Fun.

I really need to get back to San Francisco. I miss my Cable Car! No, not the tourist-infested conveyances, but this beer, the 2nd Best Sour Ive ever had (1st best goes to Cascades Agent LOrange). Sometimes I question whether my love for this ale is at least partly based on its rarity and cache, but time and again, whenever I return to Toronados and they have this on hand, I experience all over again why this holds such a special place in my heart

Bottle shared by spdyfire83 at Chez Moeder Lambic. Thank you very much my friend! You are too generous! Pours hazy light orange with a nice fine head. Very subtle aromas of vanilla, some elderflower and a slight funky touch. Silky mouthfeel with a balanced acidic sting. Taste is lime and lemon, elderberries and white grapes. Very nice beer!

Bottle, thanks ctipping - Pour a hazy yellow/amber with a white head. Lots of wonderful funk in the nose, it really hard not to keep smelling it. Tastes of tart, acidic, sourness, and some light citrus notes. Overall, I was in love and want more.

2012 bottle. Thanks BoBoChamp! Hazy golden beer with a small white head. Fruity aroma with notable yeast, and hints of caramel and oak. Fruity flavour with acidic tartness and vinegar notes, and a hint of yeast in the finish. A tad simple in character

Damned near perfect.  So sour, and purposefully so I realize, but overwhelmingly at times.  Otherwise, pure magic in a bottle.  Very thankful to the bartender who went out of his way to try and hook me up with this bottle which for awhile didnt seem like it was going to happen.  Funk, apples, lemon, sourness all in the nose.  Apples seemed to take over in the flavor department.  So good.

Bottle. Hazy gold pour with thin white head. Very funky, "clean" as in centered on the wild/funky aromas, not fruity, light earthiness, maybe a hint of something lemony. Flavor is on par with other cali sours of the same style Ive had (temptation, beatification) as a very clean sourness, lemony, with a dry finish. Very good, but not mindblowing.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours golden with low white head. Some lacing. Aroma is of fruits, sligth medical stuff, sourness, funk. Taste is of fruits, sourness, acid. Mouth puckering. Palate: Medum body. Overall: Pretty good, but not stellar.

shared with travlr and bobochamps, traded with bill. thnx dude ! 
pours blonde, as good as no foam. smells grainy, sour, apples. 
sour, good carbo, dry, realy sharp carbo, sourness, very nice !

Bottle shared at Bruces 30th Birthday Bash - CBC Clerkenwell, London. Thanks to Bruce! Pours cloudy gold with a light, white foam head. Lemony tang in the aroma. Light to medium sweet flavor with lots of lemon, big tang, some orange. Light to medium bodied with average carbonation. Rich, sour finish, quite citric and acidic. Quenching and fresh. Lots of lemony bite. Great stuff.

Bottle. [thanks bobochamp]
Pours clear yellow with no head to speak of. Aroma has light cherries, vinegar, mild lactic, some bourbon oakiness and white wine. Low carbonation, lovely dry and tart mouthfeel. Flavour is tart, oaky, peach, cherries, but with a far too burning vinegar tartness to it. There is a lot of good going on, just not that good.

Bottle (750 ml). 2012 vintage. Huge thanks to Pier-Luc, Julien and Benoit for sharing this one! Pours dark yellow/straw color with a small white head and good lacing. Aroma is cheesy with funky, barnyard, oak and slight fruity notes. Taste is moderate sour with funky notes, fruits, oak, brettanomyces, leather and light sweetness. Mouthfeel is really dry and somewhat gueuze-like. It draw the saliva. This one is really hard to rate. Theres nothing that absolutely stand out, but the balance is great and the similarities with Gueuze are really interesting. Excellent American Wild Ale!
Glad i got to try it and not have to buy it. A great LA sour, ncie acidity, lacto, lower funk, citrus tart.

Bottle from Pier-luc and Julien. Thanks guys! Pours a light orange with small head and little lacing. Aroma of funk, oak, clean sourness. Taste is bretty, funk, oak, lighht pears with some faint lemon. Low mouthfell with medium low carb. Pretty simple, not very complex but still very enjoyable.

22/IV/13 - 75cl bottle @ De Hopduvel (Gent) - BB: n/a (2013-376) Thanks to Bobochamp (and thus to Kraddel as well) for sharing the bottle!
Little cloudy beige to murky orange beer, no head. Aroma: alcohol, sherry notes, marzipan, overripe banana if very subtle, grains, biscuit, hint of cognac even, some chloride, overall sweet impression. MF: soft to no carbon, medium body. Taste: bit chemical in the start, obviously sour, but also a sweet biscuity malt layer underneath it all, staying present, lemony wood, tobacco, hinting at calvados, apple skin. Aftertaste: chloride, chemical touch, lemony, vinegar acidity, apple skin, leaving you with a very dry mouth.

75cl, Vintage 2012, exclusive American brew, thx alot to kraddel for bringing this over!, very complex sour brew, sour/woody and slightly fruity/malty, balanced, cloudy, nearly no head, very good brew

Bottle shared att CCB tasting, huge thanks to Adam. Pours hazy amber with a small off white head. Aroma is funky sour acidy fruity, excellent and balanced. Flavor is sour fruity funky, so good and balanced, slight pleasant bitterness. Finishes sour funky and fruity.

Bottle @ Bruces birthday. Cheers to the main man himself for bringing this along! The pours a hazy light amber color with a slight white head. The aromas very tart lemon squash, a bit of attic and funk yeast. The taste is strong tart lemon. Hints of general berry fruit salad. General acidic tartness. Light cheddar cheese. Light, thirst-quenching stuff. Overall, I didnt find this particularly nuanced, but its quite tasty indeed. An enjoyable experience.

Bottle at Bruces 30th celebrations, 08/02/13, big thanks to the birthday boy for sharing this one !
Hazed mid amber with a thin off white head that clears edgeward.
Nose is sour tarte berries, wood, lemon, light vinegar notes, musty funky tones, sugars, burnt notes.
Taste follows - lemon, citrus, sour apples, grandads shed, old beanos, grape, light vinegar, wood.
Medium in body with moderate carbonation lending towards a tarte and puckering finish.
Great stuff!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: 2012 bottle at Bruces 30th, massive thanks to the birthday boy for this. It pours  hazy golden-orange with a thin off-white head. The nose is sour lemon, Granny Smith apple, light funk, tart white grape, oak and subtle vinegar. The taste is fresh lemon, Granny Smith apple, sherbet, lip-smacking tartness, sour white grape, prickly citrus, tart apricot, oak and  light vinegar with a dry, tart finish. Medium body, spritzy carbonation and moderate acidity. Flavoursome and very well balanced. Ok its not as complex as the best lambics, but it makes up for it in drinkability. Delectable.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2013 2012, thanks Justin! Whoa, massive lacto aroma burst right off the bat. Previous vintages dont have this, and wow is it awesome. Settles quickly, not too carbonated, perfect. Huge citrus and yeast on the palate; certainly an American style sour. Damn, this stuff is fantastic. First rate.

2012 Bottle - graciously shared by Mike B on his birthday. Thanks Mike! Pours a clear golden with a medium fizzy head that dissipates quickly with a bit of lacing. Aroma is tart with notes of cherry, lemon, wood, and a bit of funk. Aroma profile really opens up as the beer rests. Flavor is about the same, a bit oaky, very light sweetness and medium to strong tartness. Light to medium body, prickly carbonation, almost champagne like in the mouth. Very clean well crafted beer that finishes dry. Very nice, although lacking a bit of the complexity of some of the Russian River sours, IMO.
Clear, pale orange/golden color, no foam or lacing. Tart cherry aroma with some funk. Sour cherry flavor, green apple tartness, dry, oakiness from the barrel aging, very slight funk. Very clean.

Bottle split with Chris at Toronado.  Poured a murky orange-amber with thin off-white head.  Nose of tart lemon, lactic acid, and some mild sweet malts.  Very tart with flavors of oak, peaches, lemon rinds.  Really tasty

Holzig-säuerlicher Beginn. Fruchtig, leicht nach Kirsche, rund. Die meisten Aromen verschwinden recht schnell wieder, die Säure wird milder, breitet sich dafür aber gut im Mund aus. Mild aber gut. 8/10/12/10/12/11

2007 bottle.  Gold with a nice white head.  Aroma of vinegar, leather, hay, sour apples.  Not as sour as expected, hay, lemon, lactic zing, general funk in the flavor.  This was a great American wild, but it fell far short of the hype.

Bottle shared by brew3crew. Poured a hazy golden color with an average frothy  off-white head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy sour aroma. Medium to full body with a sticky tingly texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy sour & sweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet & sour finish of moderate to long duration. This is a standout beer for style.

Bottle at the Toronado. 2010 vintage. Clear, golden liquid with big fluffy white head. Aroma of sour apples, barnyard, lemons, lacto, fruity brett and some light oak. Delicious and balanced. Taste is dry (or very light sweet) with medium sourness and notes of apples and lemons. Also very balanced. Medium bodied with low to medium carbonation. Nice to have tasted but Ive had many belgian sours thatve been better.

750 ml to snifter (BIG THANKS to brew3crew for bringing this to the tasting!). Looks great; yellowish-orange and hazy with ample carbonation and white lacing. Smells excellent; citrus, sour, and some oak. Tastes great too; much like it smells with a great mouthfeel. World class!

Vintage 2010 @ toronado SD. Yellow/golden in color, big white frothy head. Tart smell, very pleasant. Picking up some wine notes. Taste is amazing, increadible balance between the sourness & the sweetness. Leaves with oak flavors, marries well with the rest.

2007 bottle shared by Puddintane at Muckfest III...thanks Dave! - Pours hazy amber with a ring of white head. Lemon rind on the nose, tart and pretty puckering, with a creamy, yogurt malt base. Its very mellow, with hints of wood, but overall its pretty simple, which is fine by me. Really smooth taste, citrus and pale malt, creamy yogurt, and a nice tart citrus rind finish. Super smooth in the mouth, with velvet carbonation. Glad I got to try this rare treat.

Drowlands 4000th! thanks:  light hazy orange no head some floating yeast. tart funk aroma with fruity apricots, taste of fruit apricots, leather, grass with strong roasted lemon, juicy. this beer is complex but very subtle. I let it sit to warm up in the snifter, more aromatic, perfumey, with tart sour taste. This beer was great but not as good as i hoped.

Tallahassee, Fl - at drowlands 7/7/12 going away tasting party - brought by drowland from a trade he had with b3shine. Medium copper pour, absolutely no head. Intense sour aroma, hard to describe tartness to it with some hints of vinegar.  Nice intense sourness to it akin to intense sour candy like Warheads. Pick up some fresh apricots, burnt leather, some ripening vegetables in the back end. Intense tart mouthfeel. Im not exactly a sourhead - but I enjoyed this one. Excellent.

Rating 4000! Thanks to b3shine for this 2007 gem! I shared it at my going away from Tallahassee tasting. Vinegar in the aroma with some vanilla, oak, acid, and leather. Nicely tart flavor but not too tart with oak, vanilla, hay, and some more. Very nice.

Batch #1. Cheers Danny! Murky orange pour with a small white head. Nice fruity tart aroma, slightly acidic, acetic acid. Wonderful balance of fruitiness, dry grapefruit and tart acidity. Finishes dry and touches of bitter pith and the finish. Pretty tasty.

Sampled this at a sour tasting that Tomme Arthur showed up at out of the blue at. This one poured a mostly clear, yellow color with plenty of carbonation - the most carbonated beer (aside from the gushing Veritas 006) that we had all day. Almost cola-like carbonation on the side of the glasses at the start. Aroma was very subtle and subdued. Flavor is slightly sour notes with a nice amount of puckering in there.

2010 @ toronado San Fran. Pours a lignite straw yellow with a hit of haze and a nice tall fizzy head. Lots of lemon and vinegar on the nose. Subtle malt and citrus hops. Light oak character in the back. Taste was similar to the smell. Lots of lemon zest with a strong vinegar sourness to it. The malt character really was noticeable in the back. This really reminded me of a gueuze. Lots of carbonation with a light body. Slight dryness. Now that I have had this fresh, I prefer this aged. The aged 2007 seemed to have more fruit flavors where as this came across as a fresh unbalanced gueuze. Would I pay forty a bottle again? Most likely...
Reviewed on: 08-14-2010

2007 vintage. Thanks to Brad for sharing this gem.

A: cloudy, straw yellow, little lacing

S: hay, barnyard funk, citrus, slight oak

T: very complex, lingering aftertaste. A great puckering sour. Not too acidic. No bitterness. I wish it was more sour, actually. Flavors blended superbly.

M: smooth and balanced, very pleasant sourness, no alcohol taste

D: A fine brew, and easy to sip, given the style.

Bottle at Toronado.  Aroma is Brett funk, nice acidity, abundant lemon, hay, earthy.  Pours a hazy straw color, white head, some spots of lacing.  Flavor: lemon, sour apple, fairly high acidity without being puckering sour, hay and earthy notes, some light malt, hints of oak.  Light body, relatively high carbonation, very dry and refreshing finish.  Certainly a tasty brew - $40 tasty is debatable, but a fun experience at a great bar.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2013 31st August 2009Tasting at Mes and Sims flat. Dirty looking orange beer. Typical lambic nose. Dry palate.  Sour but mellow citrus. A little wood. Dry and slightly spicy finish. Drinkable but ultimately another overrated lambic.2.8  9th February 2013Bruces Birthday Bash at the Craft Clerkenwell. Tart whit e wine, a little sherry and lemon acid. Seltzer minerals bitterness. Light dry finish. Enjoyed it more this time around but never going to love this.

750ml bottle, 2010 vintage, at Toronado SF. 
Pours a clear yellow-gold with a thick and creamy white head. 
Aroma is amazing with a perfect balance of sweet and tart fruit notes of apricot, lemons, and white grapes with light oak in the background.
Flavor is simply stunning with huge, tart fruit notes of apricot, blackberry, bluberries, green apple and lemons backed by sour, vinous grapes, a touch of vinegar and yeast on the back end. 
Palate is lively, refreshing and sour at the same time with great carbonation and a dry and fruity finish. 
For sure one of the best beer Ive ever tried and loved the most (even if I am not a sour/wild superfan). Its a pity that its available only at Toronado, but probably this is also part of the appeal of this brew.

From notes.  First reviewed 10/31/2011.  Poured from a 750 mL bottle into a tulip. 2009 vintage. Thanks to Dunt for bringing this out to the whale tasting.

This has a nice hazy golden yellow color with a great compressed creamy off-white head.

The aroma is sour and funky. Lemon rind, peach, apricot, and grapefruit provide the fruity tartness, with a lot of great barnyard funk and hay.

Light pale malt flavor, and a flood of fruity sour notes start off the flavor. Apricot, peach, lemon zest, and some grapefruit toward the end. Lots of lactic sourness, a bit of oak, and some vinegar create a full sour flavor.

The mouthfeel is tart and quite acidic. Medium body with crisp carbonation. Lactic and vingeary.

The flavor is great and sour throughout, and each flavor note is so robust, I really enjoyed this beer.
one of the best beers ever. A sour IPA so delicious you cant help but drop $40 a bottle at Tornado in SF. yum!

2010 750ml shared at Toronado. Pours a light straw colored golden yellow with just a tad of haze. Wonderful subtle aroma of some barnyard funk, white wine grapes, hay, and some lemon citrus. Very nice. The flavors are perfectly balanced between some lemon rind citrus, wet oak, grapes, and some earthy grass. The acidity is perfectly balanced and is never too overwhelming. Sour, yet subtle and very well integrated. Well worth the $40 and a good start to seeing Pootie Tang later.

Shared by an awesome BA at Toronado. Pours hazy golden with white head. Aromas of citrus, oak, grapes, and fair amount of tartness. Flavors of lemon, light wood, tartness and bit of white grapes. Nice amount of mouth puckering tartness. Nice mouthfeel and body. One of best sours I have ever had.
2009 vintage. Cloudy and hazy. Very funky in the smell. Taste follows. Very smooth funkiness that sticks around for a while after the finish

Sampled at STLWills 30th b-day tasting.  Pours yellow/gold with a small white head.  The aroma has sweet/tarts, bugs, pale malt, sharp fruit, tart apples and green grapes.  Medium/light body thats on the crisp side and very refreshing.  The flavor starts with white grapes, buggy funk and fruit loops (in a good way).  The finish adds lots of peppery phenolic spice.  Very nice beer.

UPDATED: FEB 29, 2016 750 ml bottle sampled at STLWills 30th birthday party- thanks again! 2010 vintage. Pours a clear gold color with a small white ring for a head after the initial big fizz. Aroma of white grapes, lemon, dry grains, oak, and earth. Flavor of lemon, white grapes, oak, sweet malts, and dry cereal grains. Medium-bodied, with high carbonation and a sharp, tart mouthfeel. Very good overall, but theres something almost restrained in it. Re-Rate: 2014 bottle shared by Homer321 and a couple other beerbros at Toronado-SF. This one was bigger and sweeter - i.e. more balanced - than Id remembered. Really good. Upgrade.

09 vintage, tasted 07/22/2011.  Pours brilliant orange gold, thin effervescent head, looks great in the light.  Tropical, sour fruits in the initial nose (think Starbursts), a solid layer of spicy funk and leather, some orange zest.  Taste is very sour, with fruits coming first, then transitioning into some nice earthy funk, finishing dry with grape, oak notes, lasting tartness.  Adequate body with nice carbonation, but the sourness cuts into drinkability for me.  Wonderful and complex, one of the best American sours Ive come across.

This is a treat.  One of the better sour ales I have had.  Funky, sour nose I usually only associate with fine geuze.  The taste is a bomb os acidic funk, sour cherries, and the mouth drying, almost tannic granny smith apple sourness at the end.  Almost a perfectly executed sour ale.

Bottle at Toronado, 2010 vintage. Pours a clear golden with a white head. Smells wild, with sour cherries and some funk. Tastes of a medium sour tartness, and flavors I can?t begin to describe. Creamy texture. Medium carbonation. Finishes tart. Extremely delicious, though probably not worthy of the steep price ($40 for a 750ml). Glad I went for it though.

Appearance is a very light color. The aroma has a slight funk to it that is surrounded by that of peach and other fruits. The beer is much more mild than I expected. It is very drinkable. The taste is very similar to the aroma. It goes down smooth with plenty of carbonation on the tongue. Great beer

2007 vintage, courtesy of PaulUnwin.  Thanks a million for getting and sharing this bottle, Paul.  Cheers!  Pours a somewhat hazy yellow-orange with frothy white head.  Nose is vinegar, lemon, prickly tartness, tart citrus, some oak, and some mild funk.  Flavor is similar with tart citrus and acetic all over.  Oak and some bretty funk come in later, finishing with more lemon and tart citrus.  Very enjoyable.

Recently brought this to a small whale tasting.  Bottle was a 2009 vintage.  Half fingers worth of white head.  Murky peach/golden straw in color.  Nose is funky but subdued, lemon, some indiscernible citrus, white grape....really nice.  The flavor is lemon rind, peach, funk, and some citrus again.  Light mouthfeel, nice sour kick to it but not over the top at all.  Lighter carbonation, but still an ample amount.  Another winner from Lost Abbey.  We drank this side by side with a Duck Duck Gooze and we all agreed that Cable Car was far more balanced.
Fantastic American sour, opened at a tasting. Poured clear and the aroma was tart. Tasted amazing, sour, tart, fruity just a pleasure to drink!!

Vintage 2008, shared at Woodshop Classix
Appearance:  Pours a cloudy gold with no head.

Aroma:  Lemons and acetic funk.

Taste: Metallic bitterness, funk, lemon sourness and a smidgen of sweetness.

Mouthfeel: Medium no carb tingly.

Overall: Wow, very luck to have tried this. Will give my third nut for a bottle all to myself. Or maybe 40 bucks at Toronado. Either or.

A - Poured a slightly hazy golden-orange color with a finger of frothy crisp white head atop. The head faded slowly to a ring around the glass leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - The aroma is an inviting mix of sour and tart white grape and other fruit flavors. There is also some oak and vanilla as well as a nice mix of funkiness. This is one of the best smelling beers I have ever had period.

T - The beer starts off with a great mix of sour and tart white grapeish flavor. It is quite strong but not too overpowering. The oak flavor jumps in right after and starts to mellow things out a bit. By the middle of the beer, everything feels much more balanced with some vanilla and good funkiness coming through. The finish is bit again on the sour and tart with some good funkiness that linger for a while.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. The beer felt very smooth with a great mix of sour and tart throughout.

D - Very drinkable. The sour and tart flavors are outstandingly balanced from start to end here. It was really a pleasure to drink this beer, regardless of the price since I felt it was really that good.

Botella y tirador 2010 
Color amarillento con pequeña espuma,en boca es acida pero elegante,notas de barrica de vino,
muy buena "Sour"
Gracias Toronado!!

Tap at Seans 30th birthday 2010 vintage.  This was fantastic and the talk of the party that featured many other super highly rated and rare beers... all on tap mind you... Lives up to reputation, one of the best American sours for sure, very impressed here.  Super sour, lovely fruit, well rounded and sharp.  A delicious treat.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2011 I had to get one while I was at the Toronado in San Diego. 2010 Bottle poured into a goblet multiple times. 

A - Pours pale yellow with lots of little bubbles racing up the glass into a nice pillow of half finger tall white head leaving spotty wisps of lacing down the glass.
S - Quite a bit of funky brett, lemon, and other bright citric fruits blend well with the strong funk. Pretty tart but not to the point of being overpowering. Very nice stuff.
T - Lots of sourness up front giving way slowly to a mix of strong acidic lemon and some chewy brett funk. Finish is dry with plenty of lingering sour funk. Nice and light, quite refreshing actually. It did wear me down over the course of the bottle but I think that had more to do with me drinking the entire thing myself. I would love to get my hands on a bottle of this for the cellar.
M - Medium-light body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Quite the dry feel with plenty of lingering sourness that sticks around for some time.
D - Quite high. How could I not give this a five? I drank the entire bottle in one sitting and I barely felt it. Not too tart like some of the other wilds I have had recently. Nice and refreshing. I wish this wasnt such a pain in the ass to get. I would love to have a few of these for special occasions. Quite tasty stuff for sure.

Sample 2 yrs. old  Bright yellow beer; very carbonated to medium, fine white head. Dusty, lambic-like nose, but with a just a little floormop extra Brett. Dried, preserved lemons. Lambic, lemon an toasted grain flavours, even with a touch of caramel. Flavour of unripe peaches. Retronasal sulphuric, with a hint at Islay malt. Sharpish acidburn, medium bodied. Nicely aged, Im told. IMO, it misses just a bit of balance to be called really great.  Many thanks to Evan & Matt!

Poured a semi-hazy straw yellow. with a nice 2 fingers of white fluffy head.

the aroma is a mild funk with some bright lemon tartness. 

the taste is pretty good. Upfront you get a mixturen of sweetness... kinda lemon, citrus maybe... in the middle of the palate you get the barnyard and funk coming out a bit with some more sweetness. The back of the palate is where the tartness kicks in a hits the throught a little bit.

over all a great beer. This vintage is certainly young and needs some more time to develop and creat the tart sour flavors that are missing!

Bottle at Toronado, SF. 2010 vintage. Poured into a tulip.

3.5 A: First pour was a surprisingly clear darker yellow color. Two and a half fingers of light, frothy white head. Retention isnt too impressive and only some spotty lacing.

4.0 S: Good mix of fruity sweet and sour. Lots of tangy lactic acid with maybe a touch of acetic acid. A lot of oak and a good bit of vanilla, but only slightly tannic. Quite fruity like sweet tarts. Ive heard this used for DDG, but it seems to be appropriate here as well. Wild apple, lemon, generic berry, and perhaps some peach. 

4.0 T: Like the nose - a good mix of fruity and sour. Again the lactic acid is dominant with just barely any hints of acetic, though overall this is far from mouth puckering. Lemon, peach, sour green apple, and lemongrass. Again a good bit of oak and vanilla with a low tannic astringency.

4.0 M: Lighter medium body. Despite LAs reputation, this is fully carbonated and perhaps a bit too much so. Good creaminess and certainly smooth.

4.0 D: Good beer, but it isnt as impressive (at least not this vintage) as the reputation suggests. However, if nothing else, it is well balanced and highly drinkable. Good value for $20, barely acceptable for $30, but $40 is far too much after the novelty is achieved.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-17-2011 06:40:30

A few glasses on tap at Seans 30th birthday. Booya! 2010 vintage. Pours a nice glowing golden darker pour, good glow, touches of haze, with a frothy bigger white head, dies to a thicker ring and laces ok. Aromas are sour fruits, lemons and big pineapple, grapefruit, lactic acid throws sour lemonade, yogurt, and dry bready malts. Touches of yeast, bretty funk, wet oak. Mellow and balanced with still a potent sourness, lemons and pineapple fruit, grapefruits, crab apples. Touches of lacto grow into a potent sour bite, touches of apples, lemons, and pineapple. Fruity, with Lacto, some good oak, sour fruits with pineapple, pears, and apples. Sour fruits, really drinkable with wet oak, lacto, touches of funky brett, wet cheese, dust. Gorgeous, finish is fruity pineapple, grapefruit, sour lemons, apples, and lacto. Touches of brett, dusty, with light oak, wet bread. Really solid highly sessionable. A quality sour with a high drinkability. Very happy I didnt have to open my Cable Car 2009. Highly drinkable, complex, and pretty sour. An inviting beer with a lot going on, without preaching an in your face acidity or dominant element.

2010 bottle thanks to sean.  poured yellow with a white head.  aroma and flavor were both tart with lemon, funk, and a bit of buttered popcorn when it started to warm up.  an excellent sour and glad i finally had the chance to try it.

750 ml bottle shared at Toronado (SD) - My small pour was a clear light golden color with a thin white head.  Aroma was tart esters and wood.  Well, so was the flavor.  The tart esters really lingered in the finish.  Medium body.  A big thanks to Nick and Eric for the opportunity to try the bottle they bought.

Crushed at GABF 10.  So excited to try this beer.  First line I went to.  I understand why this is one of the top sours.  A wonderful balance between funkiness and sourness.  An absolute mouth-waterer.

Bottle, vintage 10. Pours milky yellow/orange in my snifter with a thick white head that fades quickly, leaving thin lacing. Aroma is sharply sour, with notes of barnyard funk and horseblanket. Flavor is much the same with a sharp acidic bite on the palate, with a lingering sour finish.

2010 Bottle thanks to ericandersnavy. Pours a clear gold with fizzy white head. Aroma is very tart, Bret, faint brown sugar. Flavor is much the same with notes of toast. Mouthfeel is light body and fizzy. Overall, I bow down to this brewery!

2010 vintage. Golden yellow in colour with beautiful white froth. Grass and yoghurt on the nose, straight up lemon and seriously tart with a hint of oak in the aftertaste. Looks the part and tastes pretty good. But maybe the hype got the better of me. The least "barrel aged" taste of any "barrel aged" beer Ive had. Still a solid beer, but a little more sour than what Id become accustomed to in California terms (softly softly). Also $40 is a considerable investment with so much good beer around in the Toronado...

2010 vintage counter-pressure 15oz bottle from a keg--thanks Sean!
Pours a very hazy, dark yellow with a tiny head. On the nose I get peach, grape skin, vanilla and some oak. Initially, the taste is juicy midway through then drops off to a very tart finish. I also pick up tangerine, orange, and lemon zest. This one is very drinkable with little notice to 7% abv. Despite the enjoyable tartness and light fruit flavors I was underwhelmed by this. Ive heard the bottles taste better however so Im looking forward to trying it another time.

Pours an absolute glowing champagne yellow orange. Medium carbonation. Nice thin layer of white lacing that was very sporadic. Aromas of unblended gueuze, peaches, champagne grapes, funky lactic notes and skunk driven brett. Taste is ultra funky sour with lemon zest, vintage oak, puckery green grapes, and french chardonay. Amazing sour but I still prefer the duck.
From a bottle,floral, bread, pale, hazy, minimal head, medium sourness, lively, light body, slick feel, a very good sour.

Drank back in 2008 a few times.  Somewhat close to a gueze, though made with bretts, so this has that epic citrusy funk going on beneath its very mild-tempered body.  Still tart and spicey enough to deserve a sweet rating in the 4 range.  Would love to try aged...

09 bottle at Toronado San Diego. The pour is golden yellow with a nice white head. The aroma is exploding with sour lemons, orange, good funky horse blanket, leather, oak, and lots of juicy fruit. The flavor does not disappoint with a great salty sour lemon/orange flavor, potent bretty funk, leather horseblanket and rope. This beer draws the mouth water like no other. It finishes dry and sour with lots of oak and lemon. One of the most enjoyable sours Ive had.

On tap at Toronado (release day). Beer is a hazy straw color, no head from pour but I cant say for sure what the head retention would look like. Aroma is great. Simple: funk and citrus, like a light geuze. The beer is comfortably tart with no detectable acetic. Some classic Brett flavors mix with tart and lemon zest with a perfectly clean finish.

Really good for its style. (Which Im not a fan)


Hazy golden pour with an interesting nose of spice, vanilla, wood and grape.

The taste was lemon, wood and bread.

2007 Vintage. This beer is amazing, plain and simple.

Beer is yellow and slightly hazy. Forms large bubbles and a large but diffuse head of very large bubbles. Carbonation is steady and strong.

STRONG chardonnay like aroma. Very sour in the nose with a slight funk that becomes more obvious the more you smell.

Beer is medium to low bodied and has a slightly citric sourness to it. Nothing much in the forward but there is a definite and growing sourness in the back of the mouth. Drinkability for this beer is really high and mouthfeel is great. Lots of carbonation on the tongue contributes to the overall sourness and feel of this beer. Im in love.

Serving type: bottle

UPDATED: APR 23, 2011 I had this 2009 bottle at dld. The beer is a murky gold not much to note. The aroma is complex starting out with lemon citrus, earthiness, and some nice tartness. The taste is the same light citrus to start some nice tart not sour notes. I had this amind veritas 003, 004 and yellow bus. It held its own but not a top wild ale.

2007 bottle thanks to Sean. Found this to be very swee

25.4 oz bottle.  Clear yellowish straw with a white cap.  Nose is doughy with green apple, violets and toffee.  Crisp and sparkling medium light with a mild sour pucker.  Taste is tart apple and dried apricot with hints of leather and oak.  Lingering sweetness; lovely.
From a 2010 bottle poured a straw color with a fair amount of head.  Great tart flavor with a lingering finish.

(GABF, this was the 2009 vintage) opaque yellow pour, lasting tan head. Nose of funk, apricot, lemon, cherries and tangerine. Taste of lemon, tart tangerine, chewable vitamin, and lactic acid. It reminds me of a gueuze, very tart linger on the palate. Nice sour!

Bottle purchased at Toronado San Diego.  Pours clear gold with a small, fizzy white head, short retention with light lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, hay, straw, meal, cereal), light hops (earthy), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of Brettanomyces, acetic acid, wine, and horse blanket.  Flavor is heavy malt (cookie, hay, straw, cereal), light hops (earthy), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of Brettanomyces, acetic acid, wine, wood, cheese, and horse blanket.  Medium body and carbonation, low warmth and creaminess with a dry finish.

Bright and clean sour...crisp and fully fermented like champagne like.  Dry with clean fruit flavors coming through.  Fewer tastes to pick through than expected.  So clean and controlled fermentation leads to a very clean sour.  It looks sharp but is a tiny but flat.  Great on the palate.

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Split with James and Dallas. Huge thank you to James for busting out this rare beauty in honor of his last day in Philadelphia and Medford. The pour is a semi-flourescent soft transparent with an initially smooth, bubbly, fluffy, one-finger off-white head. Aroma of sour lemon zest, salty cheese rind, soft tannins, leather, soap suds, lavender, Sharpie marker, honey, freshly cut wheat, and dry aromatic bitter hops. Medium bodied with a thin, tea-like, cuttingly sharp, crispyly dry mouthfeel. Mouthwatering sourness in this brew. FInishes with a superbly biting, lactic sourness and subtle creaminess. Wow. This is a tremendous beer. Well done. Cheers!
2010 Bottle shared at Mikeys tasting. Pours cloudy orange. Nose of orange zest, tart fruit and funky basement. Taste if funky tart fruit, zest, lemongrass and farmhouse yeast.

Bottle with pat and james. A thousand thank yous to james. golden hay pour with lots of head. aroma is distinctly sour. Flavor is a peachy flavor with high carbonation. very sour but incredibly rounded. James is spoiling me,

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2011 Bottle. Pours yellow/orange with a smallish white head. Aroma of lemon zest, peach, brett, and barnyard. Flavor is yeasty, tart, light with lots of different citrus and no watery mouthfeel. Fantastic, just fantastic.

Re-rate: Bottle at Toronado (duh): Pour is bright gold with a nice white head, good lacing. Aroma is similar to the first try. Flavor is just magical: mouthpuckering sour with lots of fruity zest, citrus, lemon, peach. Not so much a beer as an experience.

Shared at Pre Sex. Pours a bright lemon rind yellow with one finger of thin wispy white head. Nose is tart and a tad acetic with notes of candied fruit, citrus, and barnyard character. Flavor is tart and acidic with a nice funky yeasty character, citrus rind and some pineapple. Palate is sessionably tart and dry with a mild citrus rind character.
Orange pour with a short white head. Aroma was musty, bready, yeast. Aroma of lemon, bread, yeast, light pepper, and sour fruits. Light body, sour/fruity with a sour/tart finish.

Mostly tart and sour fruit flavors and aroma with some yeast flavor. Intense flavor and aroma. Lasting heavily sour finish. Very light bodied without being at all watery. Highly carbonated. Drinkable in small quantities.

sample at sour tasting. Bam, number 1 for the night. Amazing sour. Sour fruit (peach?), the flavors are much stronger than the other sours.  wood, lemon, and brett complement each other to a T. The sour in the beer and the finish was sensational.  After the first sip, I let the glass sit for a few minutes.  My mouth watered when I went to a second.  Exceptional beer.

Bottle. 2010 vintage. Had at Toronado San Diego! So excited. Saw this beauty behind be glass cooler and just had to have it, even at $40/bottle. Poured into a tulip glass a slightly hazed amber gold color with a nice fluffy white head that settles to a nice collar and leaves lace. The aroma is very nice, a blend of sweet grape, fruit, and a nice sourness as well. Very white  wineish. Light mothfeel with a fai bit of carbonation. The taste is nice but not as sour as I thought it would be but being the 2010, Im not surprised it hasnt fully soured up yet. Slightly sweet start like apricot  gives way to some funkiness. Finishes dry like a white wine. Splendid.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2014 Bottle 10 split with Linh at Toronado San Diego. Pours a hazy yellow body with slight white lacing. Aroma is oak, and either peach or apricot. Mouthfeel is very well balanced sourness with notes of sour fruit, funk, oak, and an incredible complexity.

Sampled at GABF 2010 in Denver, CO.  Absolutely the highlight of the festival.  I had many sampled.  Pours a hazy yellow with nice white head.  Aroma has apparent sourness, funk, hay, sour fruits.  Flavor is sour, lots of lemon.  Woody, some dust and wet wool.  Funky barnyard and oak.  Mild sweetness.  Great carbonation for almost a champagne-like mouthfeel.  Gorgeous, glorious.  The definitive example of the style.

2008 Vintage.

A: Pours a light, somewhat hazy apricot color with a nice white head and a decent amount of lacing.

S: The initial smell is quite sweet and balanced. The sourness is assertive but not at all overwhelming. Picked up quite a few notes of apricot and peach.

T: Similar to the nose in that there is a surprising amount of balance to this, unlike most other Lost Abbey sours that Ive come across. Nice stone fruit flavors alongside the lactic sourness. Overall, a very nice balance, just not quite what I was expecting. Hints of orange and lemon zest.

M: Nice sourness and low carbonation.

D: Very drinkable all around for a sour. Definitely glad to finally be able to try this one out and would love to have it again, although its definitely not quite up there with Isabelle and Veritas 004.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-18-2010

Very carbonated (2010 vintage). 3 finger head in a 6 oz wine glass. Slightly cloudy, yellow w/ a hint of orange color. Fair head retention and a bit of lacing. Smells musty, sour funk, champagne, white wine, and some light fruits.  Starts off light fruity, oakey, with some white wine and a bit of sweetness. Pretty sour, bubbly, mostly clean, with a slightly bitter finish. sourness is mostly well balanced with the rest of the beer, leaning towards too sour. Light hearted but potent flavors. The white wine of sour beers.

750 ml bottle at Toronado.  2010 vintage.  Pours a slightly hazy blonde with a large white head leaving a small amount of head on the glass.  Solid retention.  Aroma is a musty funk lemon zest, peel, a small hint of sulfur and oak.  Initial taste is a lemon zest and peel.  Then a bit of light oak and some sweetness.  A little bit of  white wine.  Funk and yeast on the finish.  Light body.  Heavy carbonation.  Very smooth.

750ml, corked & caged bottle, 2010 edition crushed at Toronado in SD in a Duvel tulip. finally had the means and opportunity to enjoy this amazing brew and it was worth every penny. pours a beautiful, clear, light, yellow-gold with a thick, creamy, bright white head and sticky rings of lace. aroma is simply outstanding with a masterful balance of sweet and tart fruit notes of apricot, blackberry, lemons, and white grapes with big, funky brett, barnyard grass, and light oak in the background with notes of blueberry jam and peach skins as it warmed. flavor is just short of perfect with huge, tart fruit notes of apricot, blackberry, bluberries, green apple skins, and lemons backed by sour, vinous grapes, a touch of vinegar, and dry funky brett with light, sweet notes of pie crust and yeast on the back end. palate is perfectly lively and refreshing yet punishingly sour at the same time with great carbonation and a bone dry, fruity finish. overall, just an amazing beer that im honored to have tried.

Its extremely tart and fruity. Good amount of lemon and zest seem really prevalent in the aroma and flavor as well. You take one sit and your cheeks really pucker a great deal. The color is almost yellow, with holds some  goldish tints to it. I remember taking the first sip and having it burn a little on the way down, deep down to the pit of my stomach. That burn was "the sickness and the cure"(dogfish slang). I was pretty much hooked on. It was great, but what made  it even better was the fact that  I got to share the experience with some good beer friends and thats what its all about people.

Bottled. yellow with white head. HUge sour tart berry fruits and so puckering taste follows really sour brett and barnyard nose. Honey, sour brett, dried fruits and vinegar. Medium bodied with rounded spritzy mouthfeel. Lemon lemon as i finish.

2010 bottle shared at the LCBS 10.  Golden yellow with pungent peach and horse blanket aromas.  This is a sour trolly with sour peach, tart lemon, funk, and brett notes.  Cant wait to revisit this at Toronado.....

2008 vintage 750 ml bottle, courtesy Beerlando. Pours a mostly clear golden yellow color and topped by a thin, off white head of foam that leaves some patches of lacing on the glass. The aroma is very fruity with tart lemons, apricots, and peaches up front followed by some vinuos white grapes and some funky yeast. The acidity is there, but not overpowering in the least. It smells really nice and begs you to take a sip. The flavor follows with the tart apricot and sour lemon up front to go with ample amount of citric acidity. Some sweet peach pushes its way through along with notes of funk from the oak, which helps smooth out some of the lactic acidity. Substantial in body, the palate sports subtle carbonation and is very crisp and dry overall. Really great tasting and refreshing sour ale. Another awesome brew from these guys.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2011 750ml bottle at SD Toronado on 7/4/11.  golden pour with a 1/4" white head.  lactic acid nose with green apples, green grapes, light barnyard funk, lemon - very well balanced.  medium body with lots of tart fruits, wheat and lemon.  well carbonated, soft and sour.  dry finish with oak and wine notes.  excellent.

2 samples from the pitcher (2009 vintage) @ GABF on 9/17/10 - my 1100th rating!  Cable Car was my first stop at GABF on Friday night and I had to get it twice... probably should have gone for a third, etc... Pours a hazy yellow color with a small white head... Nice lemon sour nose.  Medium tart body with more sour lemon/citrus, light fruit notes and some general funk.  especially acidic up front.  dry, tart sour finish ... Cable Car is an excellent sour ale that is not over the top, but just right.  I hope to make it to the Toranado one day...
Nose is lemon, strawberries, kind of metallic in its acidity like Hannsens beers.  Flavor is acidic lemon, some bretty funk.  A bit of malt remains.  Solid stuff.

#2300 !!!! 2009 bottle @ 2010 GABF. Best beer of the trip. Worth the wait in line, a couple of times. Straw yellow colored pour, massively complex aroma of tart peach, pineapple, tart sourness. I dont think this palate is advanced enough to pick up al the nuances present here. Amazingly tart & sour & flavorful. SEEK THIS OUT AT ALL COST

Light straw yellow pour, some light carbonation and a lightly funky aroma.  Flavor was initially light lemon, tart sour pear and a little yeast and butter on the aftertaste.  A very good sour, but didnt stick out as something Id try to track down in the future again

2009 bottle at GABF 2010 - quite often I find these LA sours to be far too acetic and lacking balance, but when they are on, they are sooo on - and brother, is this on - turbid wheat-colored beer - dry and oaky, tannins out the wazoo - very mild apricot and pineapple sweetness to temper the moderate acidity - moderate lacto character and low to medium funkiness - freakin delicious.

10 bottle at Toronado.  Aroma is funky off-sour with cheese rind notes.  Taste is prickly tart with some light sugary sour.  Consistent pleasant funk - you can taste the funk in the aroma before the beer actually hits your mouth.  The tart/sour flavor reaches a near eye watering level when the beer warms.  Body is light and fluffy when cold and gains a chewy quality as the beer warms.  Bitter tart/sour notes (maybe some grapefruit and peach) on the finish but quite dry.   Exceptional.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2010 2010 vintage. Tasted from bottle at Toronado. I cant believe that I am here drinking this beer! The pour is clear golden with a thick white head that sticks around and leaves a nice lace and collar. This is one of the best smelling beers I have ever had. The sour and funky aromas meld perfectly with vanilla oak. The vinegar, lemon, and funk aromas are all present, but pleasantly subdued. There is a nice malt character as well. The flavors are similar, with sour and funky notes along with lemon and oak, and a fruitiness that is closer to kiwi than anything else. The complexity of flavors rivals most Champagnes I have had. The body is light with sparkling carbonation and a long sour and oaky finish.

Toronado 23rd Anniversary.  Some generous soul shared a full vertical at the anniversary party.  I thoroughly enjoyed the beer, though Im not really sure why it deserves quite so much hype.  This is a rather funky sour.  The fresh stuff had a lot of sulfur, while the older bottles had relatively strong barnyard notes, at least for an American sour.  The beer was medium sour and very dry.  Older vintages were stronger on the sour, but it never got too puckery.  Its surprisingly restrained, almost too restrained.  A mix of vinous and dry cidery notes with hints of lemons are the fruitiest notes that Im getting.  Theres some nice oak and musty yeast flavors in there.  The brett, oak and fruit notes go together very well and the beer is easy to drink, but it seemed a bit light on complexity.  A very good sour, but Im a little surprised that this is one of the most wanted beers around.  (the 2010 version was definitely the weakest, but I could imagine it improving with time)
Bottle at San Diego Toronado. Absolutely delicious. Pours a hazy gold with a thick foamy head. So many flavors: citrus, oak, sweetness, sour, peach.

750ml bottle at Toronado. Obviously not cheap, but a great beer. Not overly sour, which I tend to like more, but exhibiting a wide range of flavors including oak, citrus, fruit, and some yeast. Golden color and not too carbonated. Awesome beer overall, and wish I could get my hands on it on a more regular basis!

Bottle shared with mrbunn at Toronado.  Pours pure yellow gold with just a thin snow dusting of white foam.  Aroma is pretty subdued, just sour grapefruit, some earthiness (oak or maple leaves, damp).  Taste is exquisite sour, mixed with brief crescendos of sweetness, oak, occassional farmyard funk, very brief and faint, and something like coconut.   Palate is wildly comples from taste to taste. Mouthfeel is just right, coating the tongue and teeth, leaving the taste of citrus essence everywhere.  Excellent.  So pleased I got the chance to try it.

Bottle (2009) shared with gorditoabd at Toronado. The excitement is palpable as the orange/good stuff is poured. Head is small and fizzy and aromas are a nice mix of straight barn and lemon funk with a little bit of a light earthy and oak edge. First sip is amazing. Even though it is a little cold, its full of lemon peel, oak, barnyard, hay or some kind of light autumn leaves. As it warms a bit there is a really odd sweetness that flits around and peeks out from time to time. After thinking and thinking about it, I decide its coconut and once the thought of coconut is in my head it really comes out strong. Mouthfeel is light and very fizzy and the sour stings the tongue a bit long after the aftertaste goes away.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Huge thanks to Maltzilla for that 07 bottle. Looks really great, I like that Lost Abbey style. The beer in the glass quite zippy, small head. Very fruity aroma. Starts quite sourish, fruity like peaches and apricot, also a bit spicy. Finish a bit less sourish, still wonderful fruity and dry, very well balanced and drinkable. A great beer!

Bottle from 2007. Thanx Kevin. The pour is sparkling hazy yellow with a neat white head. The nose is fruity with a lot of citric notes blended in. Soo fresh. On top of that there are som notes as off wet hay and a lactic touch. The taste is freshly grape-fruite-like. Its sparkling and have a pretty high carbonation and a medium to light mouthfeel. The finish ahs a kind of mild afteburner with alcohol. This sweet thing is very easy to drink and are soooo balanced between bitterness and sweetness. This one is absolutely fantastic.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 2009 Vintage

A: Like golden-orange body. Thin white bubbly head. Quickly receded and left traces of lacing behind on the glass.

S: Delicate, like fruits including peaches, apricots, lemons, and green apples. Lightly sour in the nose with a nice subtle funkyness.

T: Bam. This was good. When it comes to sours I am a sucker for the lighter citric wilds (brute, temtpation, sactification, fou foune). This one is bangin. Lots of soft peaches and apricots. An acidic lemon twist and a nice sour green apple. Some subtle tart grape skins rounds out this treat.

M: Medium bodied with a gentle rolling carbonation throughout. Sweet, tart, sour and funky. This definitely a challenging workout for the tastebuds. In the end its got a nice dry refreshing quality that leaves you thoroughly satiated.

O: Yeah. This is good. Real, real good. Wish I had more. But sadly this is it.

750ml bottle, 2008 vintage, aged about 1.5 to 2 years.  Pours mostly clear, with perhaps a very slight haze, showing a medium golden hue. A small, fizzy, off-white ring of foam forms at the head, leaving wet, broken arches of lacing on the glass after each tilt.  The aroma is ripe with fruit, very forward with apricot and dried peach notes.  A secondary wave of white grapes brings a tartness that marries decidedly well with a light, "clean", lacto-wheaty yeast funk and wisps of lemony acidity.  Overall, the scent is delectable, and it conjures a strong desire to sip.  The flavor offers notes of soured apricot and lemon up front.  Ample citric and lactic acidity gives way to lightly sweet peach at the mid point, all before finishing with a moderately wild, vinous oak finish.  Delicious stuff!  The palate is softly carbonated, very dry, and crisp, though it does sport ample body for a sour of this nature.  Its quite refreshing, overall, yet also substantive.  Very much in the vein of a Cuvee de Castleton, though less grape driven.  Excellent brew.
UPDATED: JUL 10, 2010 2009 bottle at toronado in san fran. One of the most flavorful beers Ive ever had, so much going on, but mostly a delightful tartness that finishes extremely smooth.

Sampled at DC Epic Sour Tasting 2010.  Pours a clear orange with very little spitty white head.  Aroma of oranges, light hay, lightly grassy, cotton candy.  Flavor is tart, lemons, grapefruit, apples, citrus peel, light candy, nectarines.  Finish is dry, acidic and tart.

750 ml bottle at DC Epic Sour Tasting 2010, courtesy of Spencer, thank you sir!  Clear golden, scant head and lacing.  Aroma of lemon and vacuum cleaner bag (but in a good way).  Taste is acidic grapefruit and lemon.  Decent.  Tastier with the yeast added.

BATCH #2 2008 VINTAGE
received in a trade with a generous BA thanks.
Consumed on: 12/20/09.
Overall Score: 4.35 A

Appearance: 4.0 Pours a slightly cloudy peach to pumpkin orange body with minimal crown, retention, or lace.

Smell: 4.5 Great showing of horseblanket, musky peaches, tart lemons, and lactic sourness.

Taste: 4.5 Peaches, apricots, mangos, lemon tartness, wheat tartness, green grapes, green apple skins, and a touch of dry cherry tartness. A fair amount of lactic sourness, but mainly just lots of dry tartness. A layer of barnyard as a foundation, but predominantly about the lactic acid and loads of tartness. Very enjoyable.

Mouthfeel: 4.0 Light bodied with just enough carbonation.

Drinkablity: 4.5 Goes down easy and is good to the last drop!

750 ml (2007 Vintage)  Shared at a local BA tasting.  Dark gold, creamy white head.  Deep milky cheese and lemon zest aromas warm to softer swirls of funky barnyard from start to finish.  Sour and tart lemony-pineapple flavors round well with a soft earthy funked finish. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.  Awesome brew
Pours a murky yellow. Nose is huge lactic sourness, funky barnyard, lemon, hints of leather. Flavor is big tart sour, barnyard, earthy, hay, beaitfulness.

750 ml corked and caged bottle poured a clear gold with a quickly disapating white head. Aromas of straw, lemon, horseblanket, light earthines and a hint of leather. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry tart finish. Flavors of straw, lemon zest, earthiness, light barnyard and light leather with a crisp dry lingering tart citrus finish.

Bottle at Carolina goes Sour thanks to ucusty!  A real treat.  Light orange/yellow appearance.  Aroma of fruity grapefruit, tartness, and other citric fruits.  Taste is sour tartness from sweet grapefruit and pineapple.  Acitic mouthfeel that is light bodied and tart.  Awesome brew.  Has that sweet geuze taste.  Thanks again Dave!

One of the epics I have always wanted to try. 2008 vintage. Thanks to Chris Black of Falling Rock for sharing this tasty treat. A golden yellow with light one finger off-white head and a delicious citrus aroma. Mildly funky with some citrus rind and orange peel i the finish. Flavor isnt as sour as expected, more chablis-like, with lemon zest. Suprised at the drinkability. A lightly flavored, perfect summer brew. Gracias Senor!

Bottle as part of epic sour tasting with callmemimckey.  2009 750mL bottle pours slightly hazy dark gold, decent white head.  Nose is extremely citrusy, mostly lemon, but  asolid bit of earthy funk.  Taste is exceptionally tart and acidic, but still incredibly drinkable.  Finish has some citric notes, but somewhat dry earthy finish as well.  Exceptional beer.
Thanks to Beerlando for the world class brew! Dark yellow pour. Tart, super tart, vinegar, apple aroma. Very acidic, dusty, tart, lemony, dry, yet surprisingly drinkable. Very well done.

[2007 Bottle] shared by BDR, thanks! Pours a cloudy gold with a small and dissipating head of white bubbles. Aroma is remarkably bretty, light peach, tons of barnyard, lactic tartness, and very light gravel/mineral character. Flavor has a very strong malt backbone, which really surprised me for something with this much age and brett character, theres a light, subtle tartness, slightly mineral, and the carbonation is mellow.

Thanks to Beerlando for providing rate number 1000.  It has been an honor to enjoy so many great beers with you, and the rest of the Orlando guys.  Pours a golden yellow with a fizzy white head.  Aroma of lemons, dust and a tart acidity.  Flavor is acidic and slightly watery, which takes just a bit away.  Lemon peels, dust and the grassy plains are in the flavor.  A great brew.

2007 vintage. Light clear copper color with a small bubbly white head, looks a bit dead unfortunately. Aroma is fruity, slightly cheesy with notes of bread, peach, oak, sweet apples and yeasty oranges. Flavor is mild acidic with prominent apple and orange flavors, some bitter peach with minimal lemon and funk. Mouthfeel is smooth, beer is medium bodied with fairly low carbonation. Overall simply too old and mellow at this point, still drinkable and not bad but more like a tripel than a sour ale.. Will re-rate a fresher bottle, drop me a line and Ill give you my adress...

UPDATED: APR 19, 2010 Pours a hazed, glowing orangey golden from the 750ml. bottle into a snifter at Toronados (San Diego, CA): Just came from the Lost Abbey Veritas 007 release and Im still on a high. To follow up with a glass
of Cable Car means everything. Nose of coconut, tropical mango, barnyard funk, brett, apple cider vinegar, bitter grapefruit pith, moldy blue cheese, chalky orange, pineapple, wet oak, grass, hay, and horseblanket. Vinious flavors of citrus and underipened tropical fruity esters. Not as puckering, or as carbonated as other sours, but this one is meaty, and has excellent texture. Drinkability: Believe the hype. Pairing: Prime porterhouse for two marinated in peppercorn cognac. Rebuy: Uh, duh. #405 on 17042010, DG.

07 bottle.  Cloudy gold appearance.  Very low carbonation, and this has me hoping for something like an unblended lambic to justify the hype this beer has received.  Tons of brett character in the aroma and flavor.  Just a little sour, with some Turkish apricot and a little acid.  Minimally sour.  Light fruit finish.  For the cost of this bottle, I just dont get the big deal. Isabelle Proximus is a world better.

08 bottle shared by Beerlando, Thanks!  Soft tartness with hints of honey, apple skins, floral notes as well on the nose.  Pours a rich gold with no head.  Not overly sour, citrusy with grassy notes, traces of honey malts, with a tart dry finish.  Very nice beer!

From 750 ml bottle, 2007 vintage and shared by BDR, pours a hazy golden pineapple colored brew with a fast dissipating off-white head that dissipates clean. Aroma of lemon, brett, a hint of horse blanket, papaya and powdered golden grain malt, Taste is quite smooth, mildly sour, with a hint of vanilla and tart apple flavors. Finish has a powered and dry golden grain malt with some tart apple aftertaste that slowly disappears. Three years of aging smoothed out the flavor but still enjoyable.

Bottle. Pour is hazy orange with quickly dissipating head.  Aroma is lightly tart with a notable and pleasing funk.  Also notes of peach, orange, and a floral touch akin to lavender.  Flavor is nicely tart with a pleasant horseback and hay funkiness that dominates early.  Then some softly sweet notes come though with fruity hints of peach, berries, and apple.  Really soft palate  that beckons more drinks.  A very well executed beverage.

2009 bottle shared by ucusty.  Thanks Dave.  Pours cloudy yellow with a fizzy white head. Nose is pretty incredible.  Loads of tropical fruits, funky yeast, cotton candy.  Flavor is very barnyardy with some juicy citrus and loads of funky deliciousness.  yum.

Some lemon and citrus in the nose along with some funky cheese and a bit of acetic acid providing some sharpness.  Lemon, hay, clove and pineapple are noticed on the tongue as well as some buttery notes.  Fairly dry with plenty of carbonation; this one drinks quite well.  For the price of admission, Ill take another beer, but this is definitely good.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2010 4/2010 - 09 bottle shared with Jeremy in the parking lot at  Capones. Bottle froths a bit before pouring hazy gold-honey, porous puffy white head. Rather fruity nose has significant vanilla and cheese to balance out the peach and light lemon. Flavor isnt quite as harmonious but sparkles with more lemon, peach, cheese, and a nice vanilla sweetness. Very nice mouth, juicy and lasting in the fruit combination. I didnt anticipate this one living up to the hype, but its better than Isabelle Proximus, that vanilla and citrus working wonders together. This is an all-around treat and the best Lost Abbey sour Ive had yet. 949519 10/2010 - 09 bottle shared with Jeremy shows that a lot of the softness is gone, very little vanilla or sweetness, thinner as well, heavy acidity with light burning. Still quite good, but at this point between V004 and IP for overall quality. 858417

What can I do to top Davids rating? Nothing, thats what, even though Im an educator with mega-flavor. But thanks to my man for cracking this uber-treat!!! Really lovely pour, pale orange, moderately cloudy, generous carbonation, and an all around appearance of vitality for lack of a better term. The nose is wonderfully complex, and the taste too. Granny Smith and citrus in there along with deep, fairly intense funk - hard to believe theres not more age on this considering the complexity of this facet of the beer. Makes for an interesting contrast: the youthful quality of the fruits and the aged quality of the funk. Great, great beer.
